Ethically, it's a gray area. On one hand, vaccines are important for public health and protecting the child from preventable diseases. There's also the question of how the author obtained the child's consent. If the child is old enough to understand, maybe they agreed, but if not, it's more complicated.

Another angle is whether the author has a legal duty to intervene. If the author is not a legal guardian, acting against the parents' wishes could be problematic. In some cases, reporting to child protective services might be an option if there's neglect, but anti-vaxxers aren't automatically neglectful. It's a balance between the child's safety and parental rights.

So, putting it all together, the author might be in the wrong if there's no legal justification for overriding the parents' decision.
